Award.AwardTitle: Purification of the Ge-76 for the Majorana Demonstrator
Award.AbstractNarration:
A comprehensive program in neutrino-less double-beta decay is very timely. A principal conclusion of the APS Multidivisional Study stated: "We recommend, as a high priority, a phased program of sensitive searches for neutrino-less nuclear double-beta decay." The intellectual merit of this project derives from the fact that neutrino-less nuclear double-beta-decay "is the only practical way to determine if neutrinos are Majorana particles (their own antiparticles)". This exotic nuclear decay is the most sensitive test of lepton-number conservation, an important symmetry in elementary-particle physics. In fact, if neutrinos are Majorana particles, an accurate measurement of the neutrino-less nuclear double-beta-decay half-life might well be possible; it would yield the effective Majorana mass of the electron neutrino. When combined with neutrino oscillation data, it would determine all three neutrino-mass eigenvalues.

This award provides funding to support a major Task in the MAJORANA R&D Project to establish the feasibility and cost of a one-ton 76Ge neutrino-less nuclear double-beta-decay experiment. The purification and recycling of the quantity of enriched germanium required for a one-ton experiment will have to be done efficiently to significantly reduce the cost of the experiment. The plan involves purchasing the needed equipment, setting it up, hiring and training personnel, testing the operation with natural abundance germanium, and processing the enriched 76Ge for the MAJORANA Demonstrator Module, and optimizing the efficiency.

Among the broader impacts is, and has been, new detector technology for national and homeland security and new detector technology for other basic/applied sciences.

The general area of this research is astroparticle physics, the study of the properties of elementary particles that have influence on astrophysical and cosmological processes. Neutrinos are the most prolific elementary particle in the universe, yet there is much we do not know about them. For example, their mass scale is roughly constrained but is not known. They do not posess electric charge; therefore, it would be possible for them to be their own antiparticles, called Majorana particles. If  that would be the case it would support one hypothesis, called Leptogenesis, that could explain why the universe we observe today consists only of particles, with no observable quantity of antiparticles. Leptogenesis could explain how a very tiny asymmetry of particles over antiparticles in the early universe could result in today's universe being so dominated by particles, while in the Big Bang, particles and their antiparticles were created in equal numbers.

     Therefore, research that could directly demonstrate that neutrinos are Majorana particles, or definitely are not, is fundamental and important. There is a  well known hypothesized exotic nuclear decay in which two electrons are emitted in a nuclear radioactive decay with no emission of neutrinos. This is called neutrino-less double-beta decay. For this to occur, neutrinos must be Majorana particles and must have mass. It is also well known that the only practical way to determine if neutrinos are Majorana particles is by directly observing neutrino-less double-beta decay. 

    The research supported by this grant was one component of a project to search for the neutrino-less double beta decay of the isotope germanium-76 (Ge-76). If this hypothesized decay were observed, this would constitute a major discovery. The component, or TASK supported by this grant, was part of the MAJORANA DEMONSTRATOR Project (MJD). The project was designed to operate 30-kg of ultralow background germanium detectors enriched from 7.8% to ~86% in the candidate decay isotope  Ge-76, and 10-kg of detectors with the natural isotopic abundance of Ge-76. 

     The Ge is enriched in gas centifuges in Russia and shipped to the U.S. as germanium dioxide (GeO2). The material is extremely expensive and no commercial industry was willing to purify it to the level needed to make ultra-pure Ge detectors. Therefore, the PI and his colleagues formed a team of experts to reduce the oxide and zone refine the metal to detector grade Ge, and deliver it to AMETEK in Oak Ridge, Tennessee to fabricate detectors. 

     The Team produced a processing document, purchased about $380,000 of specialized equipment, rented a 5000-sq.ft building adjacent to Electro-Chemical Systems, Inc. (ESI) and hired ESI to operate the facility. The Oak Ridge National Laboratory purchased about 37-kg of Ge in oxide form which was reduced and zone refined with a yield of greater than 98%. Later this was added to 5.5-kg of enriched Ge purchased by the NSF through a separate NSF grant. The total amount of Ge resulted in 35 enriched Ge detectors with a total mass of 29.68-kg. Leptogenesis could explain how a very tiny asymmetry of particles over antiparticles in the early universe could result in today's universe being so dominated by particles, while in the Big Bang, particles and their antiparticles were created in equal numbers. Therefore, research that could directly demonstrate that neutrinos are Majorana particles, or definitely are not, is fundamental and important. There is a well known hypothesized exotic nuclear decay in which two electrons are emitted in a nuclear radioactive decay with no emission of neutrinos. This is called neutrino-less double-beta decay. For this to occur, neutrinos must be Majorana particles and must have mass. It is also well known that the only practical way to determine if neutrinos are Majorana particles is by directly observing neutrino-less double-beta decay. The research supported by this grant was one component of a project to search for the neutrino-less double beta decay of the isotope germanium-76 (Ge-76). If this hypothesized decay were observed, this would constitute a major discovery. The component, or TASK supported by this grant, was part of the MAJORANA DEMONSTRATOR Project (MJD). The project was designed to operate 30-kg of ultralow background germanium detectors enriched from 7.8% to ~86% in the candidate decay isotope Ge-76, and 10-kg of detectors with the natural isotopic abundance of Ge-76. The Ge is enriched in gas centifuges in Russia and shipped to the U.S. as germanium dioxide (GeO2). The material is extremely expensive and no commercial industry was willing to purify it to the level needed to make ultra-pure Ge detectors. Therefore, the PI and his colleagues formed a team of experts to reduce the oxide and zone refine the metal to detector grade Ge, and deliver it to AMETEK in Oak Ridge, Tennessee to fabricate detectors. The Team produced a processing document, purchased about $380,000 of specialized equipment, rented a 5000-sq.ft building adjacent to Electro-Chemical Systems, Inc. (ESI) and hired ESI to operate the facility. The Oak Ridge National Laboratory purchased about 37-kg of Ge in oxide form which was reduced and zone refined with a yield of greater than 98%. Later this was added to 5.5-kg of enriched Ge purchased by the NSF through a separate NSF grant. The total amount of Ge resulted in 35 enriched Ge detectors with a total mass of 29.68-kg. Twenty kilograms of these enriched detectors are operating in the first of two modular arrays, in a sophisticated shield in the Sanford Underground Research Facility (SURF) in the old Homestake Goldmine in Lead, South Dakota. The second modular array will be installed at SURF in early 2016, and the exotic neutrino-less double-beta decay search will continue for several years. The Germanium Task clearly has been been very successfully completed. The facility has been closed and the equipment was shipped to the South Dakota School of Mines and Technology. There it will be used to train faculty and staff in the Ge purification process, and to perhaps even make possible improvements. The intention of the MAJORANA Collaboration is to enlarge this search to a ton-scale experiment in the future. Last Modified: 08/07/2015 Submitted by: Frank T Avignone
